A few days later, something that looked like a shiny, silver, metallic, hourglass on its side just hovered over my front lawn for 15 mins. I ran to show my father but once I got his attention of course it was gone. I don't recall ever seeing anything quite like that again. replies.context: Never used to really believe, however my son was going to college to be an Astrophysicist and when he started, we watched the space station fly overhead when we could. Then I was watching the sky every time I could at night just so I could talk to him about things he was learning. A couple of times I see a light in the sky traveling at a speed like the space station would do but it was going the opposite direction, then it stopped and darted off at incredible speed the complete opposite direction it was traveling at first. I have no idea what it was either time, but it wasn't a plane. When you look at all the planets we can see, it would be impossible to think we are alone in the universe.
That is exactly how they move. I have seen that a couple times myself since I was a child but those first two were mind melting compared to the recent stuff.

After those initial sightings, I got this idea from nowhere one day walking towards our pond. It was an inner voice, 9 years old mind you, that said word for word: "all the religions have been corrupted and it is up to you to find the truth."

I don't these unexplained events are all the same kind of phenomena. The kinds of technology they display indicate disparate origins. Earth may have attracted the attention of more than one kind of non-human intelligence which are as far above us as we are to some lower life form than us- crows or cats perhaps. 
We may need our AIs that are now in development just to communicate with them and bargain with them on our behalf. Unfortunately, I don't think we have anything to offer other than our water covered planet itself and Earth's biological diversity which is what they are probably most interested in.

I have studied this subject my whole life it seems. I can only come to the conclusion they already rule the planet and only a handful of Earth's leaders are aware of it. This was always the case in ancient times. What we call aliens use us as slaves but we civilians are not privy to this info.

context: The probability of there being life out there is exceptionally high. Whether or not there is intelligent life out there is another question, as we barely have intelligent life here on Earth, and it evolved quite recently. Extraterrestrial civilizations that can travel this far? There the chances shrink to just a small fraction above zero.

replies.context: Maybe....maybe not.....since we relate everything to our own realities and can't possibly even imagine all the variations that might exist out there.....
We can try.
The probability of life elsewhere is a complete unknown at this point.  Saying otherwise is mere speculation.
There are many principles of physics and chemistry that make it likely.

Likely?  Not really.  We know it happened, but we are the result of it, so we cannot determine how rare it is.  Sure, we know that RNA was a likely early stage, but we have no idea how many times you need to roll the dice to make it work.  That is the part we do not know how rare it is.  Nobody knows the steps needed for abiogenesis.  It could happen easily, or it could require and extraordinarily rare set of molecular events, requiring trillions of planets like earth before it happened.  We do not know.  And assigning "likely" or "unlikely" is mere speculation.

If we find life had independently started on Mars, or a signal from an intelligent civilization, for example, it would change that calculation drastically.  But that has not happened yet.

There is a vast amount of scientific literature on why life elsewhere is likely, coming from astronomers, exobiologists, biochemists studying the origin of life on Earth, mathematicians studying complexity theory, and even my fellow geneticists.
It is speculation in that ALL scientific hypotheses are speculations based on what we know. This one is just extraordinarily difficult to test. But absence of evidence is not evidence of absence. For example, in 1871 Charles Darwin "speculated" that human ancestors evolved in Africa, based upon our morphological similarities to the African hominoidea. That was basically an hypothesis, first confirmed by fossil evidence, and then further confirmed by genetic evidence.
You hit upon a good point, though, when you wrote that we "can't possibly even imagine all the variations that might exist out there....." True, but we know the possibilities are endless. Life outside Earth need not have a basis in anything similar to our genetic system other than self reproducibility.
As 'Bones' put it, "It's life Jim, but not as we know it.

None of what you say leads credence to either "likely" vs "unlikely".  Sure, we know that early chemistry on earth, with the moon in lower orbit causing huge tides causing mixing over active volcanoes, created a rich soup of possibilities.  The problem is, nobody has figured out any reasonable path by which we get to the simplest organisms we have today where ribosomes allow for the matching of particular amino acids according to a three 4-base code.  For all we know, it could have required a super extraordinary coincidence to set up that basic mechanism which itself is the basis for evolution.

We have not found evidence that life started more than once on earth, which might have been evident from, say, different encoding methods.  All life on earth uses essentially the same codon table to manufacture proteins.

Saying that trillions of earth-like planets in billions of galaxies likely have amino acids floating around doesn't overcome this difficulty.  It leaves us with NO reasonable statement about if life is likely very abundant in the universe, or if life would rarely even appear at all in a universe like ours, as it's not clear that our big bang universe is the only time it evern happened.  Could be trillions of universes had no life at all, even if all of its laws of physics were like ours.

There was a big effort by distinguished interdisciplinary scientists to come up with best guesses for each factor in the famous "Drake equation", but that was all speculation.
All I ask is that you read more of the literature if you are going to be so dismissive. And, by the way, pretty much the only way abiogenesis works is that life started more than once.

Actually, I've read quite a bit of the literature.

Nobody has suggested that abiogenesis needs life to have started more than once.  You made that up.  In fact, what is called the Central Dogma of Life uses the same coding mapping for ALL life, suggesting it originated from one genesis.  Efforts have been made to find life based on a different mapping, to no avail yet.
Life beginning more than once? I did not make that up. Stuart Kauffman explained it very well, as have others. Mathematically it would have taken more than one chance.

So the barely intelligent life has decided that it's hard for advanced civilizations to travel this far?
Maybe we're just a few meters away by interdimensional shortcuts.
No it's not probable at all.

The probability of life elsewhere in the universe is exceptionally high based on what we know about physics, chemistry, astronomy, mathematics, and biology. There is plenty of literature in each of those disciplines on this topic.

On what do you base your conclusion?
Science requires actual proof/evidence for extraordinary claims. There's no proof or evidence. End of story.

In science we have saying, especially in paleontology, that "absence of evidence is not evidence of absence." For example, in 1871 Charles Darwin wrote that it was more "probable" that humans evolved in Africa. There was no fossil evidence at the time, but he based his hypothesis on known principles of biology and geology. That was not the "End of story," as in 1924 a pre-human skull was discovered in South Africa, and literally thousands of related fossils have been found across Africa since.
So the idea of the probability of life elsewhere has the same standing as did Darwin's prescient insight of 1871.

context: This is kind of ridiculous because if they wanted us to hear them, they could easily send us a message. On the other hand, if they don't want us to hear them, they could easily use a technology like "Spread Spectrum". Which would be completely invisible to this radio telescope and we've had that technology for 20 years!

replies.context: No.....spread spectrum wouldn't be 'invisible' to 'this' radio telescope.....but it would be hard to decrypt.....although the direction of the transmissions would be easy to figure out.....the reality is far more obvious.....we wouldn't be able to decode anything because they most likely communicate with each other in a 'language' or sets of symbols that we wouldn't understand anyway........so why would they bother with encoding the message in a further attempt to prevent us from understanding it? Another 'intelligence' out there in the universe wouldn't be able to understand english without 'pictures' to go along with the worlds.....which might also be meaningless to them as their world is different.....

That's the beauty of spread Spectrum. Unless you know the signal is present and have the decoding key, it just looks like a small bump in the noise floor. Usually mistaken as simple interference. Plus, any wavelength capable of reaching us, would be high enough in frequency that it would also be highly directional. Meaning, if they weren't trying to reach somebody in our direction, we would never know it.
Who says they're trying to do anything? If their equipment is sensitive enough, 70 light years away aliens could be watching "I Love Lucy".
